reasoning: I analyzed each example to identify the pattern of feature activation in relation to genomic annotations. I observed strong, consistent activation peaks coinciding with non-coding RNA elements across multiple bacterial genomes. These primarily included tRNA genes and other functional non-coding RNAs like signal recognition particle RNA and regulatory RNAs.
findings: In all examples with high activation, the feature consistently detects non-coding RNA elements. Specifically: * tRNA genes (examples 3, 8, 9) * signal recognition particle RNA (example 4) * sRNA regulatory elements (example 2) * rRNA (example 6) The activation pattern shows sharp, strong peaks precisely at these non-coding RNA locations across diverse bacterial phyla (β-proteobacteria, γ-proteobacteria, Firmicutes, CFB group).
conclusion: This feature robustly captures non-coding RNA elements across bacterial genomes, showing biological significance.
title: Non-coding RNA element detector
description: This feature detects non-coding RNA elements in bacterial genomes with high specificity. It shows strong activation directly overlapping with tRNAs, rRNAs, signal recognition particle RNAs, and other regulatory non-coding RNAs. The activation pattern is characterized by sharp, high-amplitude spikes precisely at the non-coding RNA locations. This suggests the feature captures sequence or structural characteristics unique to functional non-coding RNAs, potentially related to their transcription, processing, or functional elements. The pattern is highly consistent across diverse bacterial phyla, including Proteobacteria (β and γ classes), Firmicutes, and CFB group bacteria, indicating conservation of these elements across evolutionary distance. The strength of activation varies by RNA type but consistently appears at non-coding RNA annotations.
